Hey Destin! We actually have something really similar to the seals! It's called the Mammalian Diving Reflex. When our faces are exposed to cold and we hold our breath, our peripheral blood vessels constrict and our heart rate drops. This allows more oxygenated blood to get to our brain, so we can stay under longer. Physiology is neat!

Was the diving edited in the order it was filmed? I ask because one of the things that PADI teach you is that "sawtooth" dive patterns are very much not recommended due to the changing partial pressured you end up with that make it virtually impossible to calculate your nitrogen exposure.

Your dive seemed to vary from 10-15m, up to less than a meter several times through the video. This would be counter to the PADI training.

Note: I am not saying this is something you cannot do. But it does require a little extra training to understand the risks involved and the adequate equipment to dive like this safely.

Even though the idea of diving between continents is really beautiful, I must lay out the truth here.
You are not really diving between continents there, touching Europe with one hand and America with the other hand. These are just surface cracks underwater, located in Þingvellir (Thingvellir). Þingvellir is located in a rift valley, a depression visible at the surface. These cracks/fissures are located on each side of the valley, parallel to the valley. The valley floor itself is rather smooth, but there are multiple cracks like that on the edges of the valley (Almannagjá, for example). These cracks are formed by tectonic forces as Þingvellir is located at a divergent tectonic boundary.
Aaaaand to ruin this completely for some of you, the tectonic boundaries at Þingvellir are not between North-America and Europe, but rather North-America and a micro-tectonic plate called "Hreppafleki".
So bascially, the diver is just diving in a deep and narrow crack in the bedrock there.

I loved Silfra. My wife and I went there in February and went snorkeling (she's a liiiiiitle bit claustrophobic so the dry suit wasn't the most fun for her). It was cold, but the fun part is that the water temperature (because it's been underground for so long) is a steady 4C all year round. It's just the trip back to the van when you turn into a popsicle that's more entertaining! :P Then again, as Canadians we're not unaccustomed to that.

I expected SmarterEveryDay to dispel the myth of "This rock is the North American continent and that rock is the European continent." It's a wide rift valley (and extremely superficial compared to the thickness of the continental crust) and the fracture you dove into is one of many parallel fracture cracks.

I still enjoyed the video, especially since I went to Iceland in August and recognized more of the places. Geographically, culturally, historically, and linguistically it's such a beautiful and fascinating place. :)
